An element $e \in M$ is called a unit element or a neutral element with respect to the law of composition on $M$ if $ea = a = ae$ holds for all $a \in M$. Such a unit element $e$ is uniquely determined by its defining property; it is usually denoted as 1.
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.

Given a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], the i-th coefficient a_i is called the coefficient of degree i.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.

An element $d \in R$ is called a greatest common divisor of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $d \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $d$ is a common divisor of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common divisor of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $a \mid x_{i}$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $a \mid d$.

An A-module is an abelian group M, together with an exterior multiplication A x M -> M, (a, x) -> a.x that satisfies the vector space axioms: a.(x+y) = a.x + a.y, (a+b).x = a.x + b.x, a.(b.x) = (ab).x, 1.x = x for elements a, b in A, x, y in M.

Kronecker's construction defines an extension field by taking the quotient of the polynomial ring of the base field by the ideal generated by an irreducible polynomial. The residue class of the indeterminate in this quotient field is a zero of the polynomial, allowing the successive adjoining of zeros of polynomials to the base field.
The extension field $L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if every element $\alpha \in L$ is algebraic over $K$.

A finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\	ext{\_q}\]$ consists of $q$ elements, where $q=p^n$ for some prime number $p$ and integer $n>0$. It is different from the residue class ring $\\[\mathbb{Z} / p^n \mathbb{Z}\]$ for $n>1$, as the latter has nontrivial zero divisors and cannot be a field.
Given a subset \(U \subset \bar{K}^{n}\), the corresponding ideal \(I(U)\) in the polynomial ring \(K[X]\) consists of all polynomials that vanish on \(U\).

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of a unit or neutral element involves the concept of a set $M$ and elements within it. A set must be defined to understand what $M$ is.
The definition of the order of a group involves counting the number of elements in a group $G$. A set must be defined to understand what the elements of $G$ are.
The definition of the coefficient of a polynomial involves the concept of a polynomial, which is a sum of terms. A set must be defined to understand the collection of terms in the polynomial.
The definition of the sum of ideals involves the concept of ideals, which are subsets of a ring. A set must be defined to understand what subsets are.
The definition of the greatest common divisor involves the concept of elements in a ring $R$. A set must be defined to understand what the elements of $R$ are.
The definition of an A-module involves the concept of an abelian group $M$ and elements within it. A set must be defined to understand what $M$ is.
Kronecker's construction involves the concept of a polynomial ring and ideals. A set must be defined to understand what the elements of the polynomial ring and ideals are.
The definition of an algebraic field extension involves the concept of elements in fields $L$ and $K$. A set must be defined to understand what the elements of $L$ and $K$ are.
The definition of a finite field involves the concept of elements in the field. A set must be defined to understand what the elements of the field are.
The definition of an ideal corresponding to a subset involves the concept of a subset $U$ and the polynomial ring $K[X]$. A set must be defined to understand what $U$ and the elements of $K[X]$ are.
The definition of the alternating group involves the concept of permutations, which are elements of a set. A set must be defined to understand what the elements of the permutation group are.
